title: Kim Kardashian sues photo editing app for $10m for using her pictures
text:
Kim Kardashian has launched a bombshell lawsuit against a photo editing app for using her photos in its advertising campaign without paying her, according to court documents obtained by DailyMail.com.

The makeup mogul filed papers against iHandy and Taplogic on Wednesday in the Superior Court of California in Los Angeles, seeking at least $10 million in damages.

Kardashian claims iHandy's Sweet Cam app used her 2017 photo, in which she is promoting her beauty line, to use in its own advertisement campaign that promoted its makeup editing app.

The mother-of-four accuses the developer of deliberately exploiting her image to 'reap millions of dollars worth of advertising and promotional services from [her] without paying for it.'

Her legal team, headed by mega lawyer Marty Singer, also blasts iHandy's reported 'ridiculous' defense that it didn't realize the photo it used was actually of Kardashian, according to legal papers.

Kim Kardashian is suing iHandy's Sweet Cam app for $10 million, according to court documents obtained by DailyMail.com

Kardashian claims iHandy used a 2017 photo of herself, in which she is promoting her beauty line, to promote its own makeup editing app. She accuses the developer of deliberately exploiting her image to 'reap millions of dollars worth of advertising and promotional services... without paying for it'

The suit states: 'Defendants incredulously and ridiculously feigned ignorance and assert that, of the billions upon billions of photographs on the Internet and Instagram, they didn't know that the one photo they pilfered and featured.... is a popular photo of Kardashian that she had posted to promote her makeup beauty line, i.e, a photo of one of the most famous and recognizable women in the world.'

iHandy is a mobile app developer that operates in Hong Kong and also has offices in California.

Co-defendant Tapologic is also named as a mobile app developer that is based in Delaware but does business in California, according to the lawsuit.

The suit adds: 'Even after notice of the infringement, iHandy continued exploiting Kardashian's image and persona, and even threatened to go after Kardashian should she advance claims to protect her rights.'

Kardashian's legal team doesn't think the sum of $10 million is too high because, according to court papers, if she agrees to an ad or endorsement campaign '(which she would only do so for a product she likes and uses, unlike Sweet Camera App) she receives significant compensation per individual Instagram post and/or for use of her image and persona in advertisement campaigns.'

According to legal documents from May, it was revealed Kim rakes in between $300,000 to $500,000 for each Instagram advertisement she posts. Sources later told TMZ that the amount was actually $1 million.

iHandy is a mobile app developer that operating in Hong Kong with offices in California and co-defendant Tapologic is also named as mobile app developer based in Delaware and does business in California, according to the lawsuit

Her legal team also blasts iHandy's reported 'ridiculous' defense that it didn't realize the photo they used of Kardashian was of the reality star, according to legal papers

iHandy's app is free to download but in-app purchases range from 99 cents to $6.99.

According to its Instagram page, the app has around 20 different filters and allows users to add 'Make Eye Color Shine & Fashion; Lipstick and Blush; and 'Hairstyles and Hair Color.'

It also offers users to 'perfect selfies with professional beauty and body retouch tools including face lift, smooth, concealer, slim and more.'

Kardashian is known world-wide for her beauty line, clothing ventures, fragrances line and from her reality show Keeping Up with the Kardashians.

Her net worth is estimated to be worth at least $350 million.

She has more than 150 million followers on Instagram and her posts regularly receive millions of likes.
